occurrences.line_text: But still suppressing gan of her inquire,
But Arthure with the rest, went onward still
Had traueld still on foot in heauie armes,
Caught like the bird, which gazing still on others stands.
So stood he still long gazing thereupon,
And sate there still, vntill the flying day
Hong still vpon his melting mouth attent;
Rather then hunt still after shadowes vaine
That two of them still fr[ow]ard seem'd to bee,
But one still towards shew'd her selfe afore;
Bad them be still, his loue should not be sold:
Still slew the formost, that came first to hand,
Still winneth way, ne hath her compasse lost:
And some of cats, that wrawling still did cry,
For still the more he stroue, the more the Knight
To crop his thousand heads, the which still new
Through smouldry cloud of duskish stincking smoke,
Pointed with mortall sting. Of her there bred
Threatning her angry sting, him to dismay:
In many folds, and mortall sting implyes.
Of Aspes sting her selfe did stoutly kill:
An heard of Bulles, whom kindly rage doth sting,
With sharpe intended sting so rude him smot,
The mortall sting his angry needle shot
And stroue to loose the farre infixed sting:
Of which in me yet stickes the mortall sting,
As if that hungers point, or Venus sting
Infixt such secret sting of greedy lust,
With sting of lust, that reasons eye did blind,
Which he to shun, and stop vile enuies sting,
Till she had duld the sting, which in her tongs end grew.
A Dragons taile, whose sting without redresse
Appear'd like Aspis sting, that closely kils,
She with the sting, which in her vile tongue grew,
As doth the poysnous sting, which Infamy
But that enuenimd sting, the which of yore,
All striuing to infixe their feeble stings,
And at the point two stings in-fixed arre,
But stings and sharpest steele did far exceed
With stings of carnall lust, and strong effort
Reproch sharpe stings, Repentance whips entwind,
For like the stings of Aspes, that kill with smart,
And with their litle stings right felly fare;
The tongues of Serpents with three forked stings,
That welnigh choked with the deadly stinke,
That him nigh choked with the deadly stinke:
Out of his stinking gorge forth steemed still,
And stinking Sulphure, that with griesly hate
Perswade vs die, to stint all further strife:
They stint their strife, and him assaile on euery side.
Yet nathemore did it his fury stint,
At length allay, and stint thy stormy strife,
To stint all strife, and foster friendly peace,
For stint of strife, and stablishment of rest
To stint all strife and troublous enmitie,
And stinted all the strife incontinent.
He yeelded, and her tooke; so stinted all their strife.
Prince Arthur stints their strife.
As when two rams stird with ambitious pride,
And stird you vp to worke your wilfull smarts?
Tho vp he started, stird with shame extreme,
Some stird the molten owre with ladles great;
Stird Porrex vp to put his brother downe;
Who stird with pitty of the stressed plight
Ne stird, till hope of life did him forsake;
That as the one stird vp affections bace,
So them with bitter words he stird to bloudy ire.
But rather stird to cruell enmity,
But rather stird to vengeance and despight,
Stird vp twixt Scudamour and Paridell,
And rather stird by his discordfull Dame,
Thereto him Ate stird, new discord to maintaine.
So all together stird vp strifull stoure,
What strokes, what dreadfull stoure it stird this day:
He is prouokt, and stird vp day and night
That with a staffe his feeble steps did stire,
When with the maistring spur he did him roughly stire.
That hand or foot to stirre he stroue in vaine:
Tho can she weepe, to stirre vp gentle ruth,
And eke vnhable once to stirre or go,
No powre he had to stirre, nor will to rize.
I euer scornd, and ioyd to stirre vp strife,
She saw not stirre, off-shaking vaine affright,
Against his praise to stirre vp enmitye
And saw it stirre: she left her percing launce,
That she note stirre. Then gan her sonne to flie
And stirre him vp to strife and cruell fight.
To stirre vp strife, and do them disagree;
To stirre vp strife, and troublous contecke broch:
The bloudie battell, and to stirre vp strife,
To stirre and roll them, like a womans eyes;
To gin awake, and stirre his frozen spright:
That striue and storme with stirre outrageous,
Sweare she is yours, and stirre vp bloudie frayes,
To stirre vp strife, twixt loue and spight and ire,
Both falling out doe stirre vp strifefull broyle,
To stirre vp strife, when most vs needeth rest,
Which troublous stirre when Satyrane auiz'd:
Like ruefull ghost, vnable once to stirre or moue.
And mutining, to stirre vp ciuill faction,
Which troublous stirre when Artegall perceiued,
With which he wont to stirre vp battailous alarmes.
Mote in them stirre vp old rebellious thought,
To stirre vp strife, and many a Tragicke stowre,
From things, that stirre vp fraile affection;
But stirred vp with different desires,
Yet stirred not at all for doubt of more,
And stirredst vp th'Heroes high intents,
It stirreth vp to sensuall desire,
Vpon the old, him stirring to be wroke
From stirring vp their stormy enmitie,
Hauing through stirring loosd their wonted band,
And kisse my stirrup; that thy homage bee.
And by his stirrup Talus did attend,
Which stirs vp anguish and contentious rage:
Well worthy stock, from which the branches sprong,
The laughing stocke of fortunes mockeries,
Large streames of bloud out of the truncked stocke
Which as a stocke he left vnto his seede;
Strikes in the stocke, ne thence can be rel[e]ast,
From royall stocke of old Assaracs line,
The noble braunch from th'antique stocke was torne
And did in stocke of earthly flesh enrace,
Yet is the stocke not lessened, nor spent,
That the drie withered stocke it gan refresh,
That of the antique Troian stocke, there grew
Sprung of the auncient stocke of Princes straine,
And all about old stockes and stubs of trees,
As withered leaues drop from their dried stockes,
But like two senceles stocks in long embraceme[n]t dwelt.
The which these Stoicke censours cannot well deny.
And ouer all a blacke stole she did throw,
Cast a blacke stole, most like to seeme for Vna fit.
Vnder blake stole hyding her bayted hooke,
And laid her stole aside. Her angels face
Thence turning backe in silence soft they stole,
For she had layd her mournefull stole aside,
And then stole fire from heauen, to animate
And linnen stole after those Priestes guize,
Her linnen stole to robe of scarlet red,
And now he to her brought part of his stolen things.
His stolen steed to thunder furiously,
So stolen from their fancies wonderment;
Or litle sparrowes, stolen from their nest,
The Briton Prince recou'ring his stolne sword,
And whilome by false Faries stolne away,
And stolne away from her beloued mate,
His owne good steed, which he had stolne, to clame;
Of armes has knighthood stolne, yet Knight art none,
Whose whelpes are stolne away, she being otherwhere.
But with sterne lookes, and stomachous disdaine,
Sterne was his looke, and full of stomacke vaine,
Corrupts the stomacke with gall vitious,
He left his stond, and her pursewd apace,
But the Blacke Palmer suffred still to stond,
Loe where the dreadfull Death behind thy backe doth stond.
But now in feare of shame she more did stond,
Doth in defence thereof full stoutly stond:
Their stedfast stonds did mightily maintaine,
In glistring gold, and peerelesse pretious stone:
And Sisyphus an huge round stone did reele
And in the midst thereof one pretious stone
And there beside of marble stone was built
Whose blessed sprites from vnderneath the stone
Dwelt fortie dayes vpon; where writ in stone
Of perle and precious stone, that earthly tong
His hart gan wexe as starke, as marble stone,
Transformd her to a stone from stedfast virgins state.
Lo now she is that stone, from whose two heads,
And yet the stone her semblance seemes to show,
Wherewith astonisht, still he stood, as senselesse stone.
The vertue is, that neither steele, nor stone
Not built of bricke, ne yet of stone and lime,
Of hewen stone the porch was fairely wrought,
Stone more of valew, and more smooth and fine,
He of his name Coylchester built of stone and lime.
An huge great stone, which stood vpon one end,
Of mightie Magnes stone, whose craggie clift
Whose face did seeme as cleare as Christall stone,
That could haue made a rocke of stone to rew,
That sure I weene, the hardest hart of stone,
There was an Altar built of pretious stone,
Through working of the stone therein yset.
With pearle & precious stone, worth many a marke;
Came to the caue, and rolling thence the stone,
The stone, which passed straunger at him threw;
And in the marble stone was written this,
Poudred with pearle and stone, and all her gowne
For neither pretious stone, nor durefull brasse,
That ruth it moued in the rocky stone,
Are now transformed into hardest stone:
And bake their sides vppon the cold hard stone,
That like a stone it fell vpon the land,
Vnder that cursed Idols altar stone;
But catching vp in hand a ragged stone,
Now beating his hard head vpon a stone,
The stone-dead quarrey fals so forciblie,
So now entombed lyes at Stoneheng by the heath.
Men into stones therewith he could transmew,
And stones to dust, and dust to nought at all;
Sometimes she raught him stones, wherwith to smite,
Emongst the pumy stones, and made a sowne,
But those three monstrous stones doe most excell
And with great pearles and pretious stones embost,
Of pearles and pretious stones of great assay,
For gold, or perles, or pretious stones an howre,
Emongst the pumy stones, which seemd to plaine
Against the stones and trees did rayle anew,
The goodly workes, and stones of rich assay,
Is lightly stricken with some stones throw;
Beaten with stones downe from the battilment,
Sith neither force of stones which they did throw,
And all the hewen stones thereof defaced,
Vppon the bosse with stones, that shined wide,
But he then stones at it so long did cast,
Though darts from shore and stones they at him threw;
And stones did cast, yet he for nought would swerue
For hardly could be hurt, who was already stong.
As seeking medicine, whence she was stong,
Th'eternall markes of treason may at Stonheng vew.
With stonie eyes; and all the hellish brood
It's now at earst become a stonie one;
But what so stonie mind (she then replyde)
And Belge selfe was therewith stonied sore,
Whiles thus he lay in deadly stonishment,
Thereat her noble hart was stonisht sore;
Whilest still she stands as stonisht and forlorne:
Doe tosse, that it will stonne thy feeble braines,
That shynd, like twinkling stars, with stons most pretious rare.
That stony hart could riuen haue in twaine,
And stony horrour all her sences fild
That could haue ouerthrowne a stony towre,
Now let the stony dart of senselesse cold
Could make a stony hart his hap to rew;
With stony eyes, and hartlesse hollow hew,
And to her said; Yet if the stony cold
With stony feare of that rude rustick mate,
Which when his german saw, the stony feare
Now seeming flaming whot, now stony cold.
Their tender feet vpon the stony ground:
What stony hart, that heares thy haplesse fate,
Next these came Tyne, along whose stony bancke
These after, came the stony shallow Lone,
The sandy Slane, the stony Aubrian,
Thus whilst his stony heart with tender ruth
Ne could he brooke the coldnesse of the stony masse.
Her to recure out of that stony swound,
Then of the certaine perill he stood in,
So stood these twaine, vnmoued as a rocke,
Astond he stood, and vp his haire did houe,
The kingly beast vpon her gazing stood;
For still to all the gates stood open wide,
Of Lordes and Ladies stood on euery side
Before the dore her yron charet stood,
And all the while she stood vpon the ground,
Which passing through, on euery side them stood
Stood long amazd, and burnt in his intent;
To thinke of wight so faire, but gazing stood,
Wherein captiu'd, of life or death he stood in doubt.
Astonisht stood, as one that had aspide
In which a rustie knife fast fixed stood,
Why wilt not let him passe, that long hath stood
And when they stood in most necessitee,
As he thereon stood gazing, he might see
And all the heauens stood still amazed with his threat.
That drowned all the land, whereon he stood;
Behind his backe vnweeting, where he stood,
Vntill they came, where that faire virgin stood;
All in the open hall amazed stood,
Which when the Peasant saw, amazd he stood,
Wherewith astonisht, still he stood, as senselesse stone.
Still as he stood, faire PhÃ¦dria, that beheld
Whylest there the varlet stood, he saw from farre
Discerne the hew thereof. He neuer stood,
The Prince now stood, hauing his weapon broke;
And though they both stood stiffe, yet could not both withstond.
Long trembling still he stood: at last thus sayd;
An huge great stone, which stood vpon one end,
A while he stood in this astonishment,
Be red; that euer open stood to all,
And in the midst of all, a fountaine stood,
The wanton Maidens him espying, stood
Whose Empire lenger here, then euer any stood.
Beside those armes there stood a mighty speare,
Great Neptune stood amazed at their sight,
Stood gaping at their gate, and wondred them to see.
The Christall humour stood congealed rownd;
There stood a stately Mount, on whose round top
So stared he on her, and stood long while amazed.
But trembling stood, and yielded him the pray;
Stood gazing, as if suddein great affright
But stood aloofe, vnweeting what to doe;
While teares stood in his eies, few drops of bitternesse.
Still as she stood, she heard with grieuous throb
They trembling stood, and made a long broad dyke,
On which there stood an Image all alone,
Had not the Lady, which by him stood bound,
So stood Sir Scudamour, when this he heard,
That still the life stood fearelesse of her foe:
Stood still a while, and his fast footing kept,
Sir Triamond at last full faint and feeble stood.
Stood still amaz'd, holding his idle sweard;
Stood gazing, filled were with rufull tine,
Thereat the Champions both stood still a space,
Now stood, came forth in hast to take his part,
Albee his turne were next; but stood there still,
In hope to take him prisoner, where he stood on ground.
Beheld, whereas he stood not farre aside,
But senselesse stood, like to a mazed steare,
And raught downe to his waste, when vp he stood,
Yet ouer him she there long gazing stood,
But stood still mute, as if he had beene dum,
Consent, that I who stood all fearelesse free,
Where one stood peeping through a creuis small,
Vnto the porch approcht, which open stood;
On either side of her, two young men stood,
Stood still by him astonisht at his lore,
Did aunswere, that of all he guiltlesse stood,
The daungerous state, in which she stood, she feared
They rose in armes, and all in battell order stood.
That all men stood amaz'd, & at his might did wonder.
He long astonisht stood, ne ought he sayd,
So stood Sir Marinell, when he had seene
Stood in the preasse close couered, well aduewed,
That like a lifelesse corse immoueable he stood.
Eftsoones he stood as still as any stake,
And them beside two seemely damzels stood,
And there before them stood a Coffer strong,
So stood they both in readinesse thereby,
As one adaw'd, and halfe confused stood;
And stood still mute, as one in great suspence,
And what he did, and in what state he stood,
And thereuppon long while stood gazing still,
But stood long staring on him, mongst vncertaine feares.
Stood open wyde to all men day and night;
Thus there he stood, whylest high ouer his head,
Which there stood gazing from the Citties wall
Stood long amaz'd, as she amated weare.
There where she stood vppon the Castle wall,
Of bloudy gore congeal'd about them stood,
And when he long had him beholding stood,
To thinke of this ill state, in which she stood,
Therefore there still he stood as in a stound,
Stood on the further bancke beholding him,
Who all this while stood there beside them bound,
Would not bewray the state in which she stood.
So stood he still long gazing thereupon,
In which all trees of honour stately stood,
But those two other which beside them stoode,
The same to all stoode alwaies open wide:
And nigh thereto a little Chappell stoode,
Ne sittest downe on that same siluer stoole,
And sitting carelesse on the scorners stoole,
Tho stooping downe she him amoued light;
That stop out of the way to ouerthroe,
There was no barre to stop, nor foe him to empeach.
He lightly snatcht, and did the floudgate stop
How without stop or stay he fiercely lept,
As he that striues to stop a suddein flood,
Which he to shun, and stop vile enuies sting,
Which wont to stop the mouth thereof, that none
Whilst none was him to stop, nor none him to restraine.
The bankes are ouerflowen, when stopped is the flood.
Till that through poyson stopped was his breath;
Whylest he of none was stopped, nor withstood.
The armed knights stopping his passage by,
and stops Occasion:
My Fathers kingdome,--There she stopt with teares;
Whereby her course is stopt, and passage staid.
And wonder of antiquitie long stopt his speach.
Malbecco stopt in great astonishment,
That stopt the entraunce with his spacious stride,
And stopt the bleeding straight, ere he it staunched thought.
He came, whose couert stopt his further sight,
For that old man of pleasing wordes had store,
Whose greedy lust did lacke in greatest store,
His heart too high through his great riches store;
Which flowed from his wounds in wondrous store,
But he could not them vse, but kept them still in store.
And did with store of euery thing abound,
Where store they found of all, that dainty was and rare.
The grace of God he layd vp still in store,
Whose pleasaunce she him shew'd, and plentifull great store.
To see his secret store.
And shewd of richesse such exceeding store,
There mournfull Cypresse grew in greatest store,
In her owne hande the crowne she kept in store,
Vntill he quite had spent his perlous store,
As if ought in this world in secret store
Sith which it had bin here preseru'd in store,
T'endow her sonne with threasure and rich store,
Yet still the bloud forth gusht in so great store,
She did enuy that soueraigne salue, in secret store.
But still remaines in euerlasting store,
And bearing with him treasure in close store,
Great store of treasure, therewith him to tempt;
The vtmost rowme, abounding with all precious store.
Which had no loue nor lemman there in store,
Which he in store about him kept alway,
In which he found great store of hoorded threasure,
And earnest search, where it was kept in store
And gan of sundry newes his store to tell,
Of Lords and Ladies infinite great store;
Keeping there close with him in pretious store
Whereof there was great store, and armors bright,
Of which he had with him abundant store,
Of which he in faire weather wont to take great store.
To weet great store of forrest frute, which hee
And store of cares doth follow riches store.
And store of cares doth follow riches store.
Hath not enough, but wants in greatest store;
That good should from vs goe, then come in greater store.
They did esteeme, and offred store of gold.
And all the Brigants flocking in great store,
Of which a store-house did with her remaine,
Then heare the storie sad, which I shall tell you briefe.
And told the storie of the mortall payne,
It were a goodly storie, to declare,
Then gan he all this storie to renew,
Shall in this storie find approued plaine;
Who all that piteous storie, which befell
To all, mongst whom this storie should be spoken,
When Calidore this ruefull storie had
Full many piteous stories doe remaine,
Whylome as antique stories tellen vs,
Yet was not so, but as old stories tell
And angry Ioue an hideous storme of raine
Vntill the blustring storme is ouerblowne;
From dreaded storme of his disdainfull spight:
When wintry storme his wrathfull wreck does threat,
Mote ought allay the storme of your despight,
His fearefull face in time of greatest storme,
Ne suffred storme nor frost on them to fall,
Then like a Centaure, then like to a storme,
With that, an hideous storme of winde arose,
An hideous storme, is by the Northerne blast
That striue and storme with stirre outrageous,
At puffe of euery storme doth stagger here and theare.
Towards them driuing like a storme out sent.
Couered with cloudie storme and bitter showre,
Like to a storme, which houers vnder skie
Against the storme of euery dreadfull stoure:
The storme of fortunes frowne, or heauens threat,
She gan to storme, and rage, and rend her gall,
Like to an hideous storme, which nothing may empeach.
Is with the blast of some outragious storme
A storme approching, that doth perill threat,
Like as a ship with dreadfull storme long tost,
Blew vp a bitter storme of foule aduersity.
Here may thy storme-bet vessell safely ride;
Long tost with stormes, and bet with bitter wind,
And seemeth safe from stormes, that may offend;
Long were to tell the troublous stormes, that tosse
By heaping stormes of trouble on them daily more?
The raging seas, and makst the stormes to flie;
Oft tossed with his stormes, which therein still remaine.
To bring forth stormes, or fast them to vpbinde,
A Fter long stormes and tempests ouerblowne,
That Knight shall all the troublous stormes asswage,
And now all weetlesse of the wretched stormes,
With stormes of fortune and tempestuous fate,
Then all the stormes of fortunes former yre
And fild her hidden caues with stormie yre,
Sleepe after toyle, port after stormie seas,
So easie is, t'appease the stormie wind
For in his shield, as thicke as stormie showre,
And shrowd their persons from that stormie stowre.
And she her selfe in stormie surges tost;
Which to allay, and calme her storming paine,
Ne storming Humber, though he looked stout;
That nothing may withstand his stormy stowre,
And as in scorne of his spent stormy spight,
At length allay, and stint thy stormy strife,
And poures it selfe forth in a stormy showre;
Like to thicke cloudes, that threat a stormy showre,
From stirring vp their stormy enmitie,
Gan blowen vp a bitter stormy blast,
All suddenly a stormy whirlwind blew
Fast locked, driuen with that stormy blast,
As being troubled with that stormy stowre;
And so forth told the story of her feare:
Then gan Sir Guyon all the story shew
The ruefull story of Sir Paridell,
He to her told the story of that fray,
For which the earth (as they the story tell)
Where faire it florished, and long time it stoud,
And all his sences stound, that still he lay full low.
Begin, and end the bitter balefull stound;
That she could not endure that dolefull stound,
Of death, that here lye dying euery stound,
He cast betwene to ward the bitter stound:
To which he turned in his wrathfull stound,
Did smyle full smoothly at her weetlesse wofull stound.
Who soone as she beheld that suddein stound,
Much was he daunted with that direfull stound,
Lightly he started vp out of that stound,
That yet of mortall stroke the stound doth beare.
To ward his bodie from the balefull stound,
Towards her chamber; at which dreadfull stound
So was he stound with stroke of her huge taile.
